title: Impulsive Axisymmetric Forcing in a Rotating Cylinder, Reversible Swirl Response, and Skyrmionic Photon Fields: Fluid Benchmarks and Fluid-Inspired Kinematic Hypotheses
description: This article is divided into two parts. Part I analyzes a rotating-tank experiment in which a short, axisymmetric impulse from a bottom impeller in a uniformly rotating cylinder produces a delayed “push–pull’’ signal on the free surface: a localized depression followed by a localized rise on the rotation axis. Using linear rotating Euler theory and standard inertial-wave dispersion \(\omega = 2\Omega k_z/k\), the work constructs an axisymmetric inertial-wave packet whose vertical group velocity \(c_{g,z}\) quantitatively explains the measured arrival time \(t_{\mathrm{arr}} \simeq H/c_{g,z}\) and its scaling \(t_{\mathrm{arr}} \propto \Omega^{-1}\). Hydrostatic coupling at the free surface, \(p'(z=H) + \rho g\,\eta = 0\), accounts for the observed bipolar surface elevation. The paper further derives a kinematic link between vertical displacement and vertical vorticity, \(\omega_z = 2\Omega\,\partial_z \xi\), and shows how axisymmetric vertical forcing generates an azimuthal swirl field \(u_\theta(r,z,t)\). For symmetric up–down forcing cycles with zero net displacement, the net azimuthal angle change is shown to vanish to leading order, demonstrating a nearly reversible swirl response in the inviscid, linear regime. Several falsifiable scaling and symmetry checks within mainstream rotating-fluid theory are listed. Part II then turns to structured light, reviewing how skyrmionic photon fields are characterized by an integer topological charge \(N_{\mathrm{sk}}^{(\mathrm{ph})}\) built from a normalized Stokes vector on the Poincaré sphere, and introducing an analogous vorticity-based surface invariant \(H_{\mathrm{vortex}}[\hat{\boldsymbol{\omega}}|\Sigma]\) constructed from the unit vorticity direction. The formal equivalence of these Chern-number-like integrals motivates a topological correspondence between knotted vorticity textures and optical skyrmion textures, and a schematic projection from vorticity to optical modes is written down as a consistency requirement rather than a detailed emission model. Throughout, the fluid benchmarks rely only on standard rotating-flow theory, while fluid-inspired kinematic time-rate hypotheses and the vorticity–photon mapping are clearly flagged as speculative outlooks built on top of established macroscopic equations.
